addressleaf.section:
15 D
e
1595 Copie of the L. Th
re
rs l
re
s to M
r
Bodley./

page.lettertext:
fol.278r
The Copie of a l
re
from the L. Th
re
r to M
r
Bodly 15 December 1595
Her
Ma
tie
hath bene acquaynted w
th
yo
r
dispatch of the xxvj
th
of November
wherein though she doth fynde howe aceptable it is to
Th'estates,
that she
suspendeth her demaund
; yet can she not remayne satsified her self w
th
this
maner of their proceeding: wherein the world must need
perceave that their
respect to her present occasione, is farre short of hers toward
them, in the tymes of
their greatest necessitie. And therefore although her Ma
tie
is pleased that you
doe lett them knowe, that she (out of Love to their Estate) is not disposed now to
contest w
th
them, but will forbeare to doe anie thing, w
ch
might serve for collour
of any disorder or confusion to aryse among them at this tyme, when there are so many
devises used to gayne the Populer, w
th
fraudulent offers of Peace: yet wold she
have you lett them knowe, that this their cowld proceeding w
th
her, must need
leave coldnesse in her disposic
o
n, though it must be not small matter, that shall
worck other seperac
o
n or alienac
o
n from them; whose good she hath preferred before
so manie particular Considerac
o
ns of her owne. And therefore for the matter
of Shipping, of w
ch
in their owne l
re
s presented by
M
r
Caron
they make
promise: you must lett them knowe, that her Ma
tie
lookes assuredly for the
forma
u
ce
as a thing whereof in noe wyse they must make defalt, because it will breed a great
Confusion in her Ma
tis
owne Preparac
o
ns. But for the sending of their Deputis,
she wold have them playnely told, that except their meaning be at the tyme of
their comy ng (besid
their formalitie of thancksgiving) to make her Ma
tie
some such
overture of present satisfaction, as may stand w
th
her honor to receave; (wherein
her Ma
tie
will be content to admit the considerac
o
n of the circumsta
u
c
w
ch
in reason
they can alledge, for not
forma
u
ce of the former proporc
o
n of her demaund
) she
shall rather take their publick comyng, as a multiplication of further scorne, then
any kynd of honorable satisfaction. And therefore she is pleased, that yo
u
shall return to the body of the Estates, the aunswere formerly sett downe. But
for asmuch as none can better deale inwardly and privatly w
th
Mons
r
Barnevill
then yo
r
self: Her Ma
tie
wold have you intimate unto him, That howsoever her Ma
tie
may
be content, externally to digest this manner of dealing for the tyme, because the co
m
on
Enemie shall not make his particular advantage of any drynesse betweene the
Queene & them: Yet can it not but worck some impression of unkyndnesse in
her Ma
ties
Princely brest, w
ch
will breake out at one tyme or other: and therefore
fol.278v
advise him, as a good Patryott to them, and a wellwiller to the Co
m
on cause; to worcke
them to some better fashion: whome you may assure, that yf they shall come over
presently w
th
power to offer as good a project at the least, or a better yf it may be,
then that w
ch
he delivered you at yo
r
last Returne; That in such case, both she will par-
ticularly have sence of his good affection, and can be contented that they shall send their
Deputies, when she will favourably receave at Messengers from her friend
and
neighbours: at w
ch
tyme, yo
u
may ether return in their Cumpanie, or some fewe
dayes before them as you see cause. Her Ma
tie
hath in this forme, geven lyke aunswere
to their Agent, whoe I doubt not will cleerly & particularly relate the same. From
the Court at Richmond the xv
th
of December 1595./
